TopicTitle: How to Kraken-proof a surface base?

Articles.Content:
Yesterday, I put finishing touches on my Minmus mine, extended the gigantors, deployed the drills, started the ISRUs, then drew the cable from the base to the tanker. The moment I plugged it in, the whole base jumped five meters up into the air, and massive explosions from behind the ISRU buildings signified a thorough RUD of the entire solar farm - seriously, not half a girder remained from it.

How to prevent this kind of accidents?

2 hours ago, Sharpy said:

...

How to prevent this kind of accidents?

I guess you're using legs?
If yes the solution is pretty simple: Wait for v1.2. Most likely the pre-release will drop within a few weeks.

1. Don't use legs or wheels.  Even after they are 'fixed' -- they are just a bad idea for permanent bases.  Sure, use them for landing, but then retract or scrap them after done..

2.) Keep the base as compact as possible.  Anything spreading out over more than ~100m will eventually encounter issues.

3.) Build on flat and level ground.  This is mostly so that when KSP reloads your craft it won't be placing part of it in a hillside.

4.) Keep most of the mass close to the center of mass.  Further distributed mass can intensify oscillations, and cause problems during physics reloading.

5.) KAS pipes are the devil as far as base stability is concerned.  If you must use KAS to attach things to your base, make sure to quick-save prior to doing it, every time.  If it doesn't work, reload and try attaching somewhere else.
